I am taking the liberty of posting a reply from Jim I copied awhile 
back o=
n the board about tekotsu:

'Checking the Yagyu article in the European NBT=
HK "Selected Fine 
Swords..." book
I found these interesting comments':

"M=
asters like shodai and nidai Yamakichibei, Nobuie and Hoan of Owari 
had
st=
udied the workmanship of old Owari and Kanayama tsuba, whose iron 
has the
=
0.6-0.8% of carbon which produces tekkotsu. Nevertheless certain 
schools
d=
emanded higher standards, among them Yagyu; the Hayashi and Shimizu 
groups=
 in
Higo; and Nobuie, Hoan and Yamakichibei of Owari; while the Katchushi 
=
group such
as Myochin used traditional forging methods.

"Forging to produc=
e the jitetsu and that for tekkotsu should be 
carried out
separately. Each=
 tsuba-ko decides the proportion of tekkotsu metal to 
use, for
example 1-5=
% of that for of jitetsu. This is cut into one centimeter 
pieces,
4-5 mm t=
hick, which are mixed with the jitetsu during forging. If the 
forging
is n=
ot good enough, it can open up later when heated in the process of
tekusara=
kashi, which results in cracks or so called forging mistakes.
Interestingly=
 enough most of the highly valued futoji-mei Nobuie 
tsuba show
those crack=
s.

The bibliography cites an article "A Brief Summary of Tekkotsu" in 
Tok=
en Bijutsu
#522, July 2000, 9-11 by a tsubako named Kazunari Naruki. I'm 
g=
uessing that
this is the source for the above comments.

Jim
